clinical_study.official_title: Real-time Auditory Feedback for Improving Gait and Walking in People With Parkinson's Disease

brief_summary.textblock: Introduction: The purpose of this study is to test the efficacy potential of using real-time positive auditory feedback to improve gait pattern in people with Parkinson's Disease (PD). The components of walking are commonly affected in patients with PD. Gait training for PD is usually based on verbal cues from the therapist that are only moderately effective. Based on good principals of gait and neuroplasticity, the Heel-To-Toe (Heel2Toe) sensor was developed to provide real-time auditory feedback during walking training. Methods: A two-group, randomized feasibility trial is planned with repeated measures of gait parameters and walking outcomes. Participants will be assessed at baseline, 3 and 6 months. Outcomes after the 5 training days will be obtained directly from the Hee2Toe device for both groups (with and without auditory feedback). The primary outcome is walking capacity measured by the Six-Minute Walk Test and the Standardized Walking Obstacle Course. Gait parameters will be captured by the Heel2Toe device Expected Contributions: Gait training using the Heel2Toe sensor will be potentially effective for improving walking pattern in people with PD.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline Six-Minute Walk Test at 3 months)

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Standardized Walking Obstacle Course (SWOC)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline Standardized Walking Obstacle Course at 3 months)
primary_outcome.description: Walking Capacity. it tests walking challenges faced by people with Parkinson: starting, stopping, turning, making motor decisions. The SWOC consists of a 12.2-m long, 0.92-m wide curved pathway, with obstacles commonly encountered in daily life.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline apathy at 3 months)
secondary_outcome.description: performance-based task to decide whether or not to exert a level of physical effort in order to obtain a (monetary) reward. The physical effort consists of squeezing an isometric hand grip dynamometer in which the effort applied varies as a function of the force required.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline lower extremity function at 3 months)
secondary_outcome.description: Health Outcome Measure on degree of difficulty with items related lower extremity function

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline QOL at 3 months)
secondary_outcome.description: Health Outcome Measure of health status

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline motivation at 3 months)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Health Related Quality of Life measured by the Visual Analogue Health State
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 3 months (Change from Baseline health related quality of life at 3 months)
secondary_outcome.description: Health Outcome Measure of quality of life

arm_group.description: The Heel2Toe group will have the 5 therapy sessions to learn to trigger the sensor with a strong heel strike and how to use device for home practice for 3 months. During the home practice, participants will be instructed to walk with the device for a minimum of 10 minutes per day in feedback mode.
The Control group will do the same 5 sessions of training and 3 months of practice but without the Heel2Toe device in feedback mode, just in data acquisition mode.

intervention.description: Heel2Toe is a device that clips on the shoe and provides an instant auditory Feedback (a beep) for each correct step characterized by putting the heel first and it provides data on gait parameters

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of Parkinson Disease and be independent in ambulation without use of walking aid
Exclusion Criteria:
- exercising three or more time per week;
- Had any additional illness that restricted their function
- Showing difficulty reading, understanding or speaking either French or English
